external-xref.#tail:
of title 44, United States Code, popularly known as the Presidential Records Act, to establish
			 procedures for the consideration of claims of constitutionally based
			 privilege against disclosure of Presidential records, and for other
			 purposes.

action-desc.#text: Received; read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

action-instruction.#text: Omit the part struck through and insert the part printed in italic

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Sec. 3. National Archives and Records Administration.
Sec. 4. Records management by Federal agencies.
Sec. 6. Procedures to prevent unauthorized removal of classified records from National Archives.

Sec. 7. Repeal of provisions related to the National Study Commission on Records and Documents of
			 Federal Officials.
Sec. 9. Records management by the Archivist.

Sec. 10. Disclosure requirement for official business conducted using non-official electronic
			 messaging account.

text.#text:
For purposes of this section, the decision to assert any claim of constitutionally based privilege
			 against disclosure of a Presidential record (or reasonably segregable part
			 of a record) must be made personally by a former President or the
			 incumbent President, as applicable.

header.#text:
Disclosure requirement for official business conducted using non-official electronic messaging
			 accounts

text.#text:
An officer or employee of an executive agency may not create or send a Presidential record using a
			 non-official electronic messaging account unless such officer or employee—

copies an official electronic messaging account of the officer or employee in the original creation
			 or transmission of the Presidential record; or

forwards a complete copy of the Presidential record to an official electronic messaging account of
			 the officer or employee within five days after the original creation or
			 transmission of the Presidential record.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, or a covered employee may not create or send a Presidential or
			 Vice Presidential record using a

text.#text: As used in this chapter, the term

includes all recorded information, regardless of form or characteristics, made or received by a
			 Federal agency under Federal law or in connection with the transaction of
			 public business and preserved or appropriate for preservation by that
			 agency or its legitimate successor as evidence of the organization,
			 functions, policies, decisions, procedures, operations, or other
			 activities of the United States Government or because of the informational
			 value of data in them; and

library and museum material made or acquired and preserved solely for reference or exhibition
			 purposes; or
duplicate copies of records preserved only for convenience.

term.#tail:
includes all traditional forms of records, regardless of physical form or characteristics,
			 including information created, manipulated, communicated, or stored in
			 digital or electronic form.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
’s determination whether recorded information, regardless of whether it exists in
			 physical, digital, or electronic form, is a record as defined in
shall be binding on all Federal agencies.

header.#text: Procedures to prevent unauthorized removal of classified records from National Archives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall prescribe
			 internal procedures to prevent the unauthorized removal of classified
			 records from the

or the
			 destruction or damage of such records, including when such records are
			 accessed or searched electronically. Such procedures shall include, at a
			 minimum, the following prohibitions:

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

An individual, other than covered personnel, may not view classified records in any room that is
			 not secure, except in the presence of

An individual, other than covered personnel, may not be left alone with classified records, unless
			 that individual is under video surveillance.

An individual, other than covered personnel, may not review classified records while possessing any
			 cellular phone, electronic personal communication device, or any other
			 devices capable of photographing, recording, or transferring images or
			 content.

An individual seeking access to review classified records, as a precondition to such access, must
			 consent to a search of their belongings upon conclusion of their records
			 review.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in a secure facility until such notes
			 and other writings are determined to be unclassified, are declassified, or
			 are securely transferred to another secure facility.

text.#text:
All notes and other writings prepared by an individual, other than covered personnel, during the
			 course of a review of classified records shall be retained by the
who has an appropriate and necessary reason for accessing classified records, as determined by the
an officer or employee of the United States Government with appropriate security clearances; or

any personnel with appropriate security clearances of a Federal contractor authorized in writing to
			 act for purposes of this section by an officer or employee of the United
			 States Government.
